title: Stansted Airport luggage screeners to strike on Bank Holiday Monday
text:
45 shares 33

comments
Workers who operate security scanners for checked luggage at the UK’s fourth busiest airport are set to go on strike tomorrow in a row over pay.
The workers are represented by the GMB union and will be off the job at Stansted Airport from 3:45am to 11:59pm on Bank Holiday Monday – one of the busiest travel days of the summer.
Employed by private contractor Mitie, around 30 employees are taking industrial action to support their claim for a three per cent pay rise.
Workers who screen checked luggage for airlines at Stansted Airport are set to go on strike tomorrow
With a turnout of 80 per cent, the security scanners voted 87 per cent in favour of a one-day strike after rejecting a 1.5 per cent offer from the company.
Even though 145,000 passengers are expected to pass through Stansted over the Bank Holiday weekend, airport officials aren’t expecting the strike to cause a significant disruption.

Share this article Share 45 shares They held a one-day walkout on 23 August, with Stansted officials claiming it had no impact on operations.
The airport said in a statement on its website: ‘If planned industrial action by members of the GMB union working for Mitie, the company that provides hold baggage screening for airlines at Stansted, goes ahead it is unlikely there will be any disruption to passenger services as Mitie has confirmed it has appropriate contingency plans in place.
Around 30 employees are taking industrial action to support their claim for a three per cent pay rise
‘If passengers are in any doubt they are advised to contact their airline for the latest information before travelling to the airport.’
The GMB union claims Mitie refused to respond to an invitation to meet with a mediator in an attempt to avert the planned strike.
Mitie Group PLC’s chief executive, Ruby McGregor-Smith, was included in the list of new peers nominated by the Conservatives last week.
